utterances: Thank you, good to be with you.
And you've defined your campaign as being the candidate who wants to most limit the role of the federal government.

Yes, I just think it is a serious problem, and that's why I don't think we should let it be dealt with by bureaucrats in Washington because they don't have a very good record.
A lot of people would like to paint myself with a brush that says if you don't want the federal government to do it, you don't want to solve the problem.

Matter of fact, the federal government invites more problem by offering what they call insurance, but - you know, against flooding and wind.

So people who enjoy the benefits of living on the beach and close to the water really are guaranteed that their houses will be rebuilt, and they said, well, we can't get insurance otherwise.
Well, they can't get it because - it's real expensive because it's very dangerous.
So it's a matter of risk.
And I think that's an objection that I've had.

Well, if FEMA does not provide disaster relief, who should?
Well, who's FEMA?
FEMA is the taxpayers, and it's debt.
They're $20 billion in debt already.
I think the states should do it.

You know, when the - when Katrina was such a disaster, there were a lot of complaints that the Guard units for the states that were involved, many of their Guard unit people were overseas, you know, worrying about war disasters.

See, I'm not opposed, under the conditions, because - I was opposed to the concept, even when it was imposed on us by an executive order, not by the Congress, but by executive order.

But we don't have any money.
We'd have to borrow the money.
We're just kidding ourselves.
And I consider the fiscal mess we're in to be very, very serious.

So what I have said is, you know, why don't we cut $10 billion a month out of the war going on over in Afghanistan, which is a total disaster, put half of that toward the deficit and put half of it back into our infrastructure or for the needs of the people we have taught to be dependent and actually try to work our way out of this.
So I think that that approach is a very responsible way of trying to deal with both the crisis, as well as our financial mess that we're in.
